INFO.description: Welcome to the easy colors game. First, you will learn each color (red, green, and blue), then you will conquer the brain blaster!
INFO.objective: Be able to identify the Filipino words for each color taught and know the Filipino words for common objects of those colors.
instructions: Navigate through each of the given colors and review the examples given.
When up for the task, you will face the brain blaster.

prep.introConcept: In Filipino, the word for 'color' is 'kulay.'
prep.exampleUsage: To say that something is a color, use 'ay kulay' followed by the color. For example, 'Ang mansanas ay kulay pula.' (The apple is red.)
prep.gameTip: Remember, colors often appear in everyday objects! Think of common items like fruits (mga prutas) or plants (mga halaman) to help remember.

TEXT.helperText: Pula means 'red' in Filipino. It's used the same way as 'red' in English, like describing a red apple (mansanas na pula) or a red car (kotse na pula).
Berde sounds a bit like 'verdant,' which means green and lush in English. Think of green grass (damo) or trees (mga puno).
Asul means 'blue' in Filipino, similar to the color of the sky (langit) or the ocean (karagatan).

QUESTIONS.question: What is the Filipino word for red?
Which color does 'berde' represent?
What is the Filipino word for blue?

INFO.description: Welcome to the medium colors game. First, you will learn more colors and their usage, then you will conquer the brain blaster!
INFO.objective: Be able to identify and use Filipino words for various colors and understand their usage in different contexts.
instructions: Navigate through each of the given colors and review the examples given.
When up for the task, you will face the brain blaster.

prep.introConcept: In Filipino, colors are used to describe various objects and their attributes.
prep.exampleUsage: For example, 'Ang kotse ay kulay pula.' (The car is red.)
prep.gameTip: Remember, colors can describe many things around you. Think of objects you see every day to help remember.

TEXT.helperText: Pula means 'red' in Filipino. It's used to describe red objects like a car (kotse na pula) or an apple (mansanas na pula).
Berde means 'green' in Filipino. It's used to describe green objects like grass (damo) or trees (mga puno).
Asul means 'blue' in Filipino. It's used to describe blue objects like the sky (langit) or the ocean (karagatan).

QUESTIONS.question: Which of the following sentences correctly uses the word 'pula'?
Translate to Filipino: 'The grass is green.'
True or False: 'Ang langit ay kulay asul' means 'The sky is blue.'
Which color is associated with the word 'berde'?
What does 'Ang kotse ay kulay pula' mean in English?

INFO.description: Letter Launch: Explore the Alphabet!. First, you will learn about accent letters in Filipino, then you will conquer the brain blaster!
INFO.objective: Be able to identify and use accent letters in Filipino.
instructions: Navigate through each of the given letters and review the examples given.
When up for the task, you will face the brain blaster.

prep.introConcept: In Filipino, accent letters are used to indicate stress or pronunciation.
prep.exampleUsage: For example, the word 'báhay' (house) uses an accent to indicate the stress on the first syllable.
prep.gameTip: Remember, accent letters can change the meaning of a word, so pay close attention to them.

TEXT.helperText: The letter 'á' is used to indicate stress on the first syllable in the word 'báhay' (house).
The letter 'é' is used to indicate stress on the second syllable in the word 'sikréto' (secret).
The letter 'í' is used to indicate stress on the second syllable in the word 'bákit' (why).

QUESTIONS.question: What is the accent letter in the word 'báhay'?
True or False: The word 'sikréto' uses the letter 'é' to indicate stress.
Which word uses the letter 'í' to indicate stress?

INFO.description: Welcome to medium level Common Phrases. First, you will learn common phrases and cultural nuances, then you will conquer the brain blaster!
INFO.objective: Be able to identify and use common Filipino phrases and understand cultural nuances.
instructions: Navigate through each of the given phrases and review the examples given.
When up for the task, you will face the brain blaster.

prep.introConcept: In Filipino culture, greetings and common phrases are essential for daily interactions.
prep.exampleUsage: To greet someone, you can say 'Kumusta ka?' (How are you?).
prep.gameTip: Remember, understanding cultural nuances can help you communicate more effectively. Think of common situations like asking for directions or ordering food.

TEXT.helperText: Masarap means 'delicious' in Filipino. It's used to describe tasty food.
Salamat means 'thank you' in Filipino. It's a common way to express gratitude.
Banyo means 'bathroom' in Filipino. It's a useful word when you need to find a restroom.

QUESTIONS.question: If something tastes good, it also tastes?
How do you say thanks?
What does banyo mean?

INFO.description: Welcome to the hard common phrases game! You will learn advanced phrases and cultural nuances
INFO.objective: Be able to identify and use a few advanced Filipino phrases.
instructions: Navigate through each of the given phrases and review the examples given.
When up for the task, you will face the brain blaster.

prep.introConcept: In Filipino culture, understanding advanced phrases and cultural nuances is essential for deeper interactions.
prep.exampleUsage: To ask for help, you can say 'Puwede mo ba akong tulungan?' (Can you help me?).
prep.gameTip: Remember, understanding deeper cultural nuances can help you communicate more effectively. Think of complex situations like discussing feelings or giving detailed directions.

TEXT.helperText: This phrase means 'Where's the closest restaurant?' in Filipino. It's useful when you need to find a place to eat.
Magkano means 'how much' in Filipino. It's used to ask for the price of something.
This phrase means 'Where am I going?' in Filipino. It's used to ask for directions.

QUESTIONS.question: Does this question ask for directions 'Saan ako pupunta?'
How do you ask 'Where's the closest restaurant?'
What does 'Magkano' mean?

INFO.description: Welcome to the hard colors game. First, you will learn advanced color names and their usage, then you will conquer the brain blaster!
INFO.objective: Be able to identify and use advanced Filipino words for various colors and understand their usage in different contexts.
instructions: Navigate through each of the given colors and review the examples given.
When up for the task, you will face the brain blaster.

prep.introConcept: In Filipino, colors are used to describe various objects and their attributes.
prep.exampleUsage: For example, 'Ang kotse ay kulay lila.' (The car is purple.)
prep.gameTip: Remember, colors can describe many things around you. Think of objects you see every day to help remember.

TEXT.helperText: Lila means 'purple' in Filipino. It's used to describe purple objects like a car (kotse na lila) or a flower (bulaklak na lila).
Kahel means 'orange' in Filipino. It's used to describe orange objects like a fruit (prutas na kahel) or a sunset (takipsilim na kahel).
Rosas means 'pink' in Filipino. It's used to describe pink objects like a flower (bulaklak na rosas) or a dress (damit na rosas).

QUESTIONS.question: Which of the following sentences correctly uses the word 'lila'?
Translate to Filipino: 'The fruit is orange.'
True or False: 'Ang bulaklak ay kulay rosas' means 'The flower is pink.'
Which color is associated with the word 'kahel'?
What does 'Ang kotse ay kulay lila' mean in English?

INFO.description: Welcome to the easy numbers game. First, you will learn the numbers 1 to 10 in Filipino, then you will conquer the brain blaster!
INFO.objective: Be able to identify and use the Filipino words for numbers 1 to 10.
instructions: Navigate through each of the given numbers and review the examples given.
When up for the task, you will face the brain blaster.

prep.introConcept: In Filipino, numbers are used to count objects and describe quantities.
prep.exampleUsage: For example, 'Isa, dalawa, tatlo' (One, two, three).
prep.gameTip: Remember, numbers are used in everyday situations. Think of counting objects around you to help remember.

TEXT.helperText: Isa means 'one' in Filipino. It's used to count a single object.
Dalawa means 'two' in Filipino. It's used to count two objects.
Tatlo means 'three' in Filipino. It's used to count three objects.
Apat means 'four' in Filipino. It's used to count four objects.
Lima means 'five' in Filipino. It's used to count five objects.
Anim means 'six' in Filipino. It's used to count six objects.
Pito means 'seven' in Filipino. It's used to count seven objects.
Walo means 'eight' in Filipino. It's used to count eight objects.
Siyam means 'nine' in Filipino. It's used to count nine objects.
Sampu means 'ten' in Filipino. It's used to count ten objects.

How do you say 'two' in Filipino?

Labing-tatlo means 'thirteen' in Filipino. It's used to count thirteen objects.
Labing-apat means 'fourteen' in Filipino. It's used to count fourteen objects.

Labing-walo means 'eighteen' in Filipino. It's used to count eighteen objects.
Labing-siyam means 'nineteen' in Filipino. It's used to count nineteen objects.
Dalawampu means 'twenty' in Filipino. It's used to count twenty objects.

prep.introConcept: In Filipino, numbers are used to count objects and describe quantities.
prep.exampleUsage: For example, 'Limampu, isang daan, limang daan' (Fifty, one hundred, five hundred).
prep.gameTip: Remember, numbers are used in everyday situations. Think of counting objects around you to help remember.

TEXT.helperText: Limampu means 'fifty' in Filipino. It's used to count fifty objects.
Isang daan means 'one hundred' in Filipino. It's used to count one hundred objects.
Limang daan means 'five hundred' in Filipino. It's used to count five hundred objects.
Isang libo means 'one thousand' in Filipino. It's used to count one thousand objects.
Limang libo means 'five thousand' in Filipino. It's used to count five thousand objects.
Isang milyon means 'one million' in Filipino. It's used to count one million objects.

QUESTIONS.question: What is the Filipino word for fifty?

True or False: 'Limang daan' means 'five hundred' in Filipino.

INFO.description: Welcome to the story of 'Ang Tatlong Baboy' (Three Little Pigs). Follow the classic story, but this time in Filipino.
INFO.objective: Be able to understand the Filipino words used in the story and learn how to use them in everyday situations
instructions: Navigate through each page of the story.
Click the 'Translate' button to see the English translation of the text.
When up for the task, you will face the brain blaster.

prep.introConcept: When reading, taking the time to see what each word means can help you pick up on the language!
prep.exampleUsage: For example, you can figure out that 'May tatlong baboy' means 'There were three pigs.'
prep.gameTip: Look for phrases such as 'gumawa ng mga bahay' (built houses) and 'ligtas ang mga baboy' (the pigs were safe).

TEXT.text: May tatlong baboy na gumwa ng mga bahay.
TEXT.englishText: There were 3 pigs who built houses.

TEXT.text: Ang una ay gumamit ng dayami, ang ikalawa ng kahoy, at ang ikatlo ng bato.
TEXT.englishText: The first used straw, the second used wood and the third used bricks.

TEXT.text: Dumating ang lobo at sinubukang pumasok. Hinipan niya ang unang dalawang bahay, at nasira ang mga ito.
TEXT.englishText: The wolf came and tried to get in. He blew down the first two houses which broke.

TEXT.text: Ang bahay ng ikatlong baboy ay matibay, kaya hindi ito nasira.
TEXT.englishText: The third pig's house was strong and did not break.

TEXT.text: Umalis ang lobo, at ligtas ang mga baboy.
TEXT.englishText: The wolf left and the pigs were safe.

TEXT.text: Masaya silang kumain at nagsaya buong gabi.
TEXT.englishText: They happily ate and celebrated all night.

QUESTIONS.question: What is the Filipino word for red?
Which color does 'berde' represent?
What is the Filipino word for blue?
Ang langit ay kulay asul.
Ang mansanas ay kulay asul.
The word for 'sky' in Filipino is 'langit'.

INFO.description: Welcome to the easy colors game! First, you will learn each color (red, green, and blue), then complete a quiz!
INFO.objective: Be able to identify the Spanish words for each color taught and know the Spanish words for common objects of those colors.
instructions: Navigate through each of the given colors and review the examples given.
When up for the task, you will face the brain blaster.

prep.introConcept: In Spanish, the word for 'color' is 'color.'
prep.exampleUsage: To say that something is a color, use 'es color' followed by the color. For example, 'La manzana es color roja.' (The apple is red.)
prep.gameTip: Remember, colors often appear in everyday objects! Think of common items like fruits or plants to help you remember.

TEXT.helperText: Rojo means 'red' in Spanish. It's used the same way as 'red' in English, like describing a red apple (manzana roja) or a red car (coche rojo).
Verde is similar to 'verdant,' which means green and lush in English. Think of green grass or trees.
Azul means 'blue' in Spanish, similar to the color of the sky or the ocean.

QUESTIONS.question: What is the Spanish word for red?
Which color does 'verde' represent?
If 'azul' means blue, what color is the sky in Spanish?

prep.introConcept: In Spanish, the word for 'color' is 'color.'
prep.exampleUsage: To say that something is a color, use 'es color' followed by the color. For example, 'La manzana es color roja.' (The apple is red.)

TEXT.linkedText: Había tres cerditos que construyeron casas.
TEXT.englishLinkedText: There were 3 pigs who built houses.

TEXT.linkedText: El primero usó paja, el segundo madera, y el tercero ladrillos.
TEXT.englishLinkedText: The first used straw, the second used wood and the third used bricks.

TEXT.linkedText: Llegó el lobo e intentó entrar. Sopló las dos primeras casas y las destruyó.
TEXT.englishLinkedText: The wolf came and tried to get in. He blew down the first two houses which broke.

TEXT.linkedText: La casa del tercer cerdito era fuerte, por lo que no se rompió.
TEXT.englishLinkedText: The third pig's house was strong and did not break.

TEXT.linkedText: El lobo se fue, y los cerditos estaban a salvo.
TEXT.englishLinkedText: The wolf left and the pigs were safe.

TEXT.linkedText: Feliz, comieron y celebraron toda la noche.
TEXT.englishLinkedText: They happily ate and celebrated all night.

QUESTIONS.question: What is the Spanish word for red?
Which color does 'verde' represent?
If 'azul' means blue, what color is the sky in Spanish?

prep.introConcept: In Portuguese, the word for 'color' is 'cor.'
prep.exampleUsage: To say that something is a color, use 'é da cor' followed by the color. For example, 'A maçã é da cor vermelha.' (The apple is red.)
prep.gameTip: Colors often appear in everyday objects! Think of common items like fruits (frutas) or plants (plantas) to help you remember.

TEXT.linkedText: A maçã é da cor vermelha.
TEXT.helperText: Vermelho means 'red' in Portuguese. It describes things like a red apple (maçã vermelha) or a red car (carro vermelho).

TEXT.linkedText: A grama é da cor verde.
TEXT.helperText: Verde means 'green' in Portuguese, used for grass (grama) or trees (árvores).

TEXT.linkedText: O céu é da cor azul.
TEXT.helperText: Azul means 'blue' in Portuguese, similar to the color of the sky (céu) or the ocean (oceano).

QUESTIONS.question: What is the Portuguese word for red?
Which color does 'verde' represent?
What is the Portuguese word for blue?
O céu é da cor azul.
A maçã é da cor azul.
The word for 'sky' in Portuguese is 'céu.'

INFO.description: Welcome to the medium colors game! First, you will learn each color (red, green, and blue), then complete a fun challenge.
INFO.objective: Be able to identify the Portuguese words for each color taught and know the Portuguese words for common objects of those colors.
instructions: Navigate through each of the given colors and review the examples given.
When ready, you will take on the brain blaster.

prep.introConcept: In Portuguese, the word for 'color' is 'cor.'
prep.exampleUsage: To say that something is a color, use 'é da cor' followed by the color. For example, 'A maçã é da cor vermelha.' (The apple is red.)
prep.gameTip: Colors often appear in everyday objects! Think of common items like fruits (frutas) or plants (plantas) to help you remember.

TEXT.linkedText: A maçã é da cor vermelha.
TEXT.helperText: Vermelho means 'red' in Portuguese. It describes things like a red apple (maçã vermelha) or a red car (carro vermelho).

TEXT.linkedText: A grama é da cor verde.
TEXT.helperText: Verde means 'green' in Portuguese, used for grass (grama) or trees (árvores).

TEXT.linkedText: O céu é da cor azul.
TEXT.helperText: Azul means 'blue' in Portuguese, similar to the color of the sky (céu) or the ocean (oceano).

QUESTIONS.question: What is the Portuguese word for red?
Which color does 'verde' represent?
What is the Portuguese word for blue?
O céu é da cor azul.
A maçã é da cor azul.
The word for 'sky' in Portuguese is 'céu.'

INFO.objective: Be able to identify the Filipino words for each color taught and know the Filipino words for common objects of those colors.
instructions: Navigate through each of the given numbers and review the examples given.
When up for the task, you will face the brain blaster.

prep.introConcept: In Filipino, the word for 'color' is 'kulay.'
prep.exampleUsage: To say that something is a color, use 'ay kulay' followed by the color. For example, 'Ang mansanas ay kulay pula.' (The apple is red.)
prep.gameTip: Remember, colors often appear in everyday objects! Think of common items like fruits (mga prutas) or plants (mga halaman) to help remember.

TEXT.helperText: Pula means 'red' in Filipino. It's used the same way as 'red' in English, like describing a red apple (mansanas na pula) or a red car (kotse na pula).
Berde sounds a bit like 'verdant,' which means green and lush in English. Think of green grass (damo) or trees (mga puno).
Asul means 'blue' in Filipino, similar to the color of the sky (langit) or the ocean (karagatan).

QUESTIONS.question: What is the Filipino word for red?
Which color does 'berde' represent?
What is the Filipino word for blue?
Ang langit ay kulay asul.
Ang mansanas ay kulay asul.
The word for 'sky' in Filipino is 'langit'.

TEXT.linkedText: Havia três porquinhos que construíram casas.
TEXT.englishLinkedText: There were 3 pigs who built houses.

TEXT.linkedText: O primeiro usou palha, o segundo madeira e o terceiro tijolos.
TEXT.englishLinkedText: The first used straw, the second used wood and the third used bricks.

TEXT.linkedText: O lobo chegou e tentou entrar. Ele soprou as duas primeiras casas, que caíram.
TEXT.englishLinkedText: The wolf came and tried to get in. He blew down the first two houses which broke.

TEXT.linkedText: A casa do terceiro porquinho era forte e não caiu.
TEXT.englishLinkedText: The third pig's house was strong and did not break.

TEXT.linkedText: O lobo foi embora, e os porquinhos estavam seguros.
TEXT.englishLinkedText: The wolf left and the pigs were safe.

TEXT.linkedText: Felizes, comeram e celebraram a noite toda.
TEXT.englishLinkedText: They happily ate and celebrated all night.
